thread.title: Kenya: We've Won Safaricom Charges War - Equity
thread.title_full: Kenya: We've Won Safaricom Charges War - Equity

title: Kenya: We've Won Safaricom Charges War - Equity
text:
Kenya: Cabinet Meets Over Teachers Strike By Constant Munda 
Equity Group said yesterday it was undeterred by Airtel Kenya's threats to exit the market even as it insisted that Safaricom is "arbitrarily abusing market dominance". 
Equity's mobile banking platform, Equitel, is riding on Airtel's dormant infrastructure under the Mobile Virtual Network Operator licence issued April, last year. 
Chief executive James Mwangi said the giant banking group would have options and that Airtel's exit would only pave way for acquisition of the India's Bharti Airtel-owned telco. 
"We are not worried about any company exiting... because exiting doesn't mean closing, it means selling to somebody else," Mwangi told media and investor briefing. "Since the [Equity's] value proposition is so good, we will speak with whoever comes on board with same terms and conditions(as Airtel's)." 
He however wondered why Airtel was contemplating an exit on grounds that the regulator, Communications Authority, was taking 18 months to check perceived "abuse of dominance" by Safaricom. 
"Instead of saying you are leaving -where are you leaving to when you have nowhere to go to - we (should) fight until we get our right," he said. 
Equity has over the last month been in a fresh feud with Safaricom over the latter's successful application to the Central Bank to increase fees for banks transferring cash from their accounts to Safaricom's globally successfully mobile money platform, M-Pesa. 
Mwangi claimed Equity has won the battle, citing media reports on Tuesday that CBK would install a private sector-led Payments Association of Kenya to deal with inter-network charge disputes in line with National Payment System Act of 2011. 
"The problem is...fully solved and in a permanent way. That arbitrary abuse of dominance power is over," he said. "The Central Bank has been an excellent arbitrator." Kenya
